As regards the condition of the valley at the period of the battle, it is not too much *to adopt Baker's description of it as marshy; and, although there is now no trace of a stream in it, the ‘torrens' of which our chronicle speaks may have been some tiny brook, perhaps not much wider than a ditch, yet sufficiently troublesome for the passage os baggage-waggons. At all events it is quite clear that Baker cannot be speaking of the Miausson, the only stream now laid down near the field. Across the valley is the hill, lying behind La Cardinerie, which the prince's division occupied at the opening of the battle, and round which the capta] de Buch led his men.
